member.name: P:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.Mode
member.summary: FTP data connection mode: Active (client waits for incoming data connections) or Passive (client establishes data connections). Passive is default.
member.remarks: You can specifies ports to use in active mode by using property.

member.name: P:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.ActiveModePorts
member.summary: Gets or sets the port range used in mode. This has no effect for passive mode transfers.

member.name: P:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.ActiveModeAddress
member.summary: Gets or sets the IP address announced to the FTP server when establishing an mode data transfer. Don't set this unless needed. By default, the value of this property is which means that the address of the network interface is used instead. This has no effect for passive mode transfers.

member.name: P:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.IgnorePassiveModeLocalAddress
member.summary: Gets or sets the value indicating if a workaround for FTP servers that announce private range IP addresses even though a public IP was used for control connection. By default, when such address is detected, an IP address announced by the server in response to PASV command is ignored. Control's connection address is used instead. Default is .

member.name: P:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.IgnorePassiveModeAddress
member.summary: Ignores address sent by the FTP server for data connections in mode in response to PASV command. Default is .

member.name: P:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.TransfersDataType
member.summary: Gets or sets data type used for all data transfers. Default is (I).

member.name: P:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.ASCIIChangeNewLines
member.summary: Specifies if new lines should be changed when is set to transfers. Default is false.

member.name: P:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.ProtectionBufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size, in bytes, of the encoded data blocks to be sent or received during file transfer.

member.name: P:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.DontUseCompression
member.summary: Forces the compression not to be used. You should set this field before connecting to the remote server. Default value is false.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the compression is used for data transfers.

member.name: M:Limilabs.FTP.Client.Ftp.KeepAliveDuringTransfer(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Sets the interval, at which a NOOP command is sent on the control conenction during a file transfer.
member.param: Specifies interval at which a NOOP command will be sent on the control conenction during transfer. indicates that no NOOP command should be sent.
member.remarks: Setting keep alive can be useful to prevent routers from prematurely closing the command channel while a long data transfer is taking place. It is generally not necessary to set a value less than 15 minutes (900 seconds). Not all FTP servers support receiving NOOP commands during file transfers. It's been observed that these servers will act strangely: not reply to the command, or only send the reply after the file transfer has completed. This will cause the component to throw a timeout exception since it's expecting a reply within the timeout period. If you see this behavior, consider not using this method.

member.name: T:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission
member.summary: Represents FTP permissions returned using perm fact in response to MLSD command ( method or when is supported)

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.Append
member.summary: The "a" permission applies to objects of type=file, and indicates that the command may be applied to the file named.

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.CreateFile
member.summary: The "c" permission applies to objects of type=dir (and type=pdir, type=cdir). It indicates that files may be created in the directory named. That is, that a and commands are likely to succeed, and that and commands might succeed if the file named did not previously exist, but is to be created in the directory object that has the "c" permission. It also indicates that the command is likely to succeed for names in the directory.

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.Delete
member.summary: The "d" permission applies to all types. It indicates that the object named may be deleted, that is, that the command may be applied to it if it is a directory, and otherwise that the command may be applied to it.

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.ChangeFolder
member.summary: The "e" permission applies to the directory types. When set on an object of type=dir, type=cdir, or type=pdir it indicates that a command naming the object should succeed, and the user should be able to enter the directory named. For type=pdir it also indicates that the command may succeed (if this particular pathname is the one to which a would apply.)

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.Rename
member.summary: The "f" permission for objects indicates that the object named may be renamed - that is, may be the object of an command.

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.List
member.summary: The "l" permission applies to the directory file types, and indicates that the listing commands, , NLST, and may be applied to the directory in question.

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.CreateFolder
member.summary: The "m" permission applies to directory types. It indicates that the command may be used to create a new directory within the directory under consideration.

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.Purge
member.summary: The "p" permission applies to directory types. It indicates that objects in the directory may be deleted, or (stretching naming a little) that the directory may be purged. Note: it does not indicate that the RMD command may be used to remove the directory named itself, the "d" permission indicator indicates that.

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.Read
member.summary: The "r" permission applies to type=file objects, and for some systems, perhaps to other types of objects. It indicates that the command may be applied to that object.

member.name: F:Limilabs.FTP.Client.FtpPermission.Write
member.summary: The "w" permission applies to type=file objects, and for some systems, perhaps to other types of objects. It indicates that the command may be applied to the object named.
